												Very fun racing game! I used to have this years ago on my PS2, but I don't play that anymore. I finally decided to get it for my computer, and it's just like I remember: plenty of crashing and destruction!It's better than FlatOut 1 in the fact that there are better/more cars to choose from, and the same with tracks, but not with free roam. As for the demolition derbies, they are also plenty of fun. It's nice when a game isn't too easy, so I do like the fact that there is a contact timer of about 44 seconds, meaning you have to smash into someone at some point. The AI is also certainly smarter than the first FlatOut, thus adding to the difficulty of derbies and races. It only has 3 more derby arenas than the first one, for a total of 6, so there certainly could have been a few more arenas.Lastly, you can't forget the minigames! There are oddities such as Royal Flush, Baseball, Bowling, and a few others where you have to fling yourself out of the car. These are pretty entertaining, especially with friends. It can get slightly monotonous by yourself though.All in all, this is still lots of fun for a game made in 2006!

												FlatOut 2 came out just 2 years after its predecessor and was released in June 2006. That would make it around the time when I actually first played the game with my friends. Man, the game was good. Recently I have decided to try it out again, and to my surprise the game still rocks! 


YouTube™ Video: Flatout 2 - A 2016 Gamplay Review and Retrospective - Is it still worth getting? 

			Views: 2,411		

			A short review of Flatout 2 with the sole purpose of providing information on if it is still worth playing today? Thanks for looking!		

FlatOut 2 is by far the best racing game of it's kind that I have played. Long time has passed since the release, but everything about the game still seems really good from graphics to gameplay. Unfortunately there's no online but LAN via other software is possible. Do not fret though, single player is extremely fun. The AI is scripted very well. By the end of 2-3 cups you will understand how every individual AI drives. They don't always want to win now, some of them want to crash others players cars. It does not mean that it will always be you though. So expect some random stuff happen to you during the game. Never under estimate the opponent.

By: Princess Gay X




The  soundtrack just blew my mind. I do like the type of music that this game has, but to think that I know almost all of the songs in the game just makes it so much better. This game has lots of big names  like Rob Zombie, Wolfmother and .... Nickleback. But what's more important is that the car engine sound like a boss, the noise is so sexy, sometimes I just lower the music volume. 


Sexy beast 
A Screenshot of FlatOut 2
By: Princess Gay X




It been almost 9 years now, but the graphics will not hurt your eye, in fact this game probably eclipsed a ton of racing games which came out around the same time. Car details are very good, both brand new and half destroyed. The maps look just awesome, textures still look good to this day. Human ragdolls are a bit on the downside again, but you do not tend to fly out as often anymore. Overall, I am extremely happy about the graphics and how they are still so good even eight years after. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276072What else is important about the racing game for PC players, a game that was also realsead on consoles? The answer is controls. Finally, I played a game, where you can easily steer just by using your arrows on the keyboard. Game is very playable without a joystick. It also feels that the developers made it easier to control cars in the first place. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276142By now your thinking that there must be something bad about the game. Well, I am going to tell you that there are non big things that will off put you. There are minor things about interacting with physical objects, but that's about it guys, this game is almost perfect! http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351137260Replayabilty is massive, once you discover the LAN. To conclude, this game deserves the price. If there's no sale then just buy it. You will not regret it. The game is so good, you will end up driving at least for the next 5 hours before taking a break.

												FlatOut 2 is an absolute get! I can't recommend it enough!I was dying for a new racing game to play and happened to have a few bucks in my Steam wallet from selling cards and on a whim bought it for a mere $2.49! Which was an out right steal for this game. If I had known how fun this was I would of gotten it sooner, its regular $10 asking price is still a steal for this!Fun:• Slamming into people feels nice, heavy and like you're really doing some damage to'em.• It has variety in spades. Be it flinging your driver across water, through burning hoops or for playing poker. Demolition derbies, short simple circuit tracks and the varied longer race courses, theres a lot here.• The sound design is astoundingly good. It has probably the best tire squeals I've ever heard in a racing game. Most games have 1 long squeal which sounds more like the car is doing a burn out than struggling to maintain grip. In this it has a nice stutter to it, like it really is struggling and about to give. You can hear rocks knocking around your wheel well and under your car on the dirt tracks, something I notice games overlook a bit.• The cars are a great. With a heavy focus on muscle cars for the most part, which is great cause I lost my taste for racing games when they suddenly became mostly about nasty little rice burners (looking at you Need for Speed.). Only about 1~2 cars handled bit squirrely- *coughSpeedevilcough* -and the real only customization to the cars is being able to pick a color.• The AI actually will crash and wreck without you around, and the follow the same rules you are ei. getting hung up on random track debris and not taking turns perfectly all the time! They maintain a nice difficulty without ever truly being fustrating. Though I'm sure Sofia Martinez will be on your list of people you want dead.• It. has. Cheat codes.Meh:• The soundtrack is just well.. meh. At no point will there ever not be a guitar or drum playing. It tends to get a little grating to listen to near constant noise. Overall its not the worst soundtrack I've ever heard but its nothing I'd listen to outside of the game.Flaws:• Only real flaw I can think of is that the menus would not work with my controller.• Also you really don't get anything for 100%ing it. Quite the shame, least its a fun 100% to get.Only thing I wish it had was weather and the abilitly to mirror and reverse the tracks. In the end you should just get it. GET IT NOW!

												One of the best arcade/vehicular combat racing games ever. More about high speed and destroying all the decorations, rather than Flatout 1 where the tracks have more tricky cornering and where you had to pick which objects to collide with. What I like:-Nice looking cars, they are based on real life models suitably. Though the models are somewhat low-poly strangely, Flatout 1 has more detailed models..-Pretty okay graphics still overall although NFS Most Wanted from 2004 for example already had more advanced things regarding textures, shaders and lighting system..I mean, FO2 doesn't have bump mapping, not all shadows in FO2 are realtime shadows and no realtime reflections either..yet FO2 has sharp textures in comparison for one.-Good sound design, the cars..although they kinda lack volume and intensity..FO1 had more intense engine noises. Ultimate carnage corrected the problem by having a clipping distortion effect for the player's engine noise, it made the fo2 sounds more aggressive suitably. The sound of small rocks in gravel roads pinging and ricocheting in the wheel wells is remarkably awesome and lovely to hear, makes the countryside tracks all the better to race in. Good crash sfx, when you crash subtly versus hard the difference is plenty audible :) although there could have been more crunching metal and stressing metal type sounds.-Handling physics, there is clearly difference between all the drive types. Though there could have been some handling nuances for some cars..aside of their grippiness rating, there is no other differentiation for the handling between cars.-The gameplay. Cathartic. You race with cars of 3 different type, derby cars which are beat up, slow yet durable old cars. Then race cars, something alike to scuffed and worn rally cars, they are 80's-00's era cars with moderate top speeds and acceleration, and mid range toughness. And lastly the street class with import tuners and muscle cars, these sleds are devilishly fast but lack in durability overall, made worse by crashes in that class being usually on high speeds :d There is the usual circuit races and to complement those there are the derbies where the one with most collective score from damaging opponents wins..not necessarily last man standing wins, the special event races such as a oval gravel track, figure of eight and some others. Lastly there is the silly stunts, where you throw your driver out of the windshield, for example to stick to a wall in high jump to score the best height. In all races but stunts, there will be crashing..often indirect crashing too, from pushing your opponent to an obstacle.What I don't like..No choice to have the bloom off yet the other post processing effects on. The bloom doesn't help to make an upbeat atmosphere, rather it is obtrusive and blinding..no idea how I back then played FO2 with the post processing on.8.5/10.

But the game makes it feel like they didnt put a story mainly because they didnt have the money for it.We arrive at the problems. The Gameplay is great..but depends on your car. With the handy ones you can really have fun,  and with tuning even the tanks make fun (especially when you can crash everyone in your way and be a monster on the road!) but if you are no pro in racing games then you will frustrate. The AI is fair on the start and there you can really have fun: driving, crashing around and feel like a badass. fantastic. but then the AI is so fast and drives like on rails (while you drive like on ice) and acheives 300kmh easily. and scripted enemies....we all hate them. you can crash someone into a wall and he gets last, 1 round later he is 2cond again. The game is unfair, really damn unfair. your respawn sets you almost 4 places back (and you respawn often, trust me) and enemies drive like on drugs. BUT here the element I told comes in. crashing. you cant win without it because the enemies are way faster than you. so you need to master slamming an enemy that tries to overtake you in the perfect moment. But if you master crashing and put your focus on it muahahaha that game will make you happy. nothing is as pleasing as slamming into the back of an annoying enemy and sending it right into a wall! crashing feels great and looks great, the driving never feels slow and the crashes rarely feel annoying. ..if you master it ofc XDThere are also many little mini games that entertain a lot but as the main game..frustrating to the max, you must be literally perfect to pass them on 1st. and in the later game you only have speed rings an such. very sad because derbys are the most fun thing on the game and it isnt possible to take faster cars into a low class derby.now the main problem of the game: EVERYTHING ELSE THAN THE GAMEPLAYIm serious, this game feels like the makers didnt had any time to make anything else than the cars and races, and not even them are good made.we have about 20tracks or a bit more/less, so repeats are pretty often and nothing was planned. you cant see which races exactly or how many laps a cup will have (and the game only has cups!) neither we can play a single race in the career mode. you are foced to take a cup. they much probably forgot to add many functions. because the cups are based on points like normal (first gets 10 points, second gets 8 and so on) but you can repeat ever race as often as you want in a row, that takes both away. the challenge of cups and the fun of a single track. Cars..oh damn that point is sad. there are quite many cars and they drive different from car to car, but mostly in 3 areas: understerring as hell, drifting as hell, or like on ice. with tuning they will drift a lot but in a good controlable way (never take a full muscle car without tuning, even with max tuning some of them wont ever make a corner with more than 100kmh) but even here everything lacks. you cant tune any visual except the colour (on some only), but the worst..you can only choose it once! you bought it in black but want it blue? well sucks to be you, buy it again. and the tuning..theres no way to test tuning and once you bought a tuning, you cant uninstall it! nitro makes your car 3 points better in nitro but 3 worse in power (about) want to unisntall the nitro? not possible. The cars wont give you a good speed feel in 80% of the game, only full tuned cars feel fast and reach 250kmh or more. Music: Music is pretty okay, all rock songs (the sound designer was a extrem rock fan it seems) from back then very famous bands (fall out boy, nickelback, wolfsmother) that are nice to hear but if you dont like rock..you are fu**ed. and even every rock lover will hate the songs soon. why? there are only about 20songs! and since they all sound similiar you soon get annoyed by them, especially because..NO MUSIC PLAYER. seriously not even a single bit. You cant skip a song, cant play the last one, restart it, manage songs that can play or anything. heres a song, deal with it. sad when you restart a race 5 times only to have a song you like. songs skip everytime you join or leave a race, so you can control is a bit XD but yeah horrible. The game really lacks on all else than the basic stuff. you got no proper replay function, so if you had an awesome moment like a super crash round where you killed 4 cars..well no one will believe you because you cant replay it! (i recommend recording while playing because the game will give you great moments) I killed 6 enemies once and it was a photfinish with 2 broken cars but i will forever be the only one who saw it.the game really feels super small and repeating , the few things there are fun (and unfair) but it feels like the game was made either without love, money, or time (or all of them). If the game is in sale, i recommend, and if you love crashing in games and dont mind lack of content, try it out! no game I ever played gave me such a good feel in rampages and demolition, also it isnt so damn slow. But yeah, for fans of normal race games like nfs todays, I recommend you to not get this game, its fun, feels fun to play and is always great for a 15minutes playing, even till today, but you will wish yourself the makers added more. The concept and ideas are great and has potential they sadly never ever used.I love this game till today but even a hardcore fan like me hates many parts of this game.

												While the first game was hard FlatOut 2 is beyond easy & hard. It is arbitrary, luck decides if you win or not and you as the player have little influence on that.There are two main issuesThe engine/the car behaviorYou cannot predict how your car will react during a jump or hitting an obstacle. Sometimes it runs smoothly, sometimes you will lose your position or advantage. Therefore there is little space in getting better or master the game, because you don't get proper feedback which action benefits you and which one will be punished.You will find at the bottom a video I've done about two stunts. The only thing I do is pressing throttle without pausing it, so there is no room for variation. I do this in both stunts. Two exact same actions from the player result in different outcomings.The AI/your opponentsSome of them are trolls, not interested in winning the race just ramming other cars and putting themselves at the tail end while giving you a hard time.The other extreme are the flawless ones, usually using one of the higher level cars which you have to unlock first. Catching up with them happens rarely. They usually drive clean and boost forwards if you are getting close. Starting at the last position puts you in huge disadvantage against those.The other thing is that the AI adapts to you. Are you driving faster or have you upgraded your car? They get better as well, so the difficulty seems to stay stable. At least to a certain point. Buying a new car with much better values makes the races easier, but not as much as I expected.Some small annoyances-The starting position varies, but most times I got the last place or something near that.-Later in the game you may have to repeat races a couple times to collect the amount of money to buy a car you've just unlocked. Winning all level 1 races doesn't guarantee you having enough money for a Level 2 car.-Strangely a Level 1 car isn't necessary good enough to compete in Level 1 races. I once had to grind for a better one and repeated the races.-NPCs get fixed cars from the start of a class and some of them get ones from a higher tier. It would be fairer if everyone would use a car from the same level.All in all: Driving good doesn't get rewarded, you need a certain amount of luck. Both, losses and victories, felt cheap and latter one never satisfied me. I was just relieved to be over the current race.Now the most important point:Does this all make the game unenjoyable? It depends.Are you looking for a serious racing game? Is anything but 1st place not an option to you? Then skip this one. It started pretty easy and was fun, but the further I got into the game the more the races turned into bitter and teeth-gnashing hours of retries which felt more like playing roulette and waiting untill the ball hits your number.If you don't care about the mentioned issues, because just beating the game is enough for you or you just want to have a bit random wanky car physics fun, you might wanna try it. At least it won't hurt as long as you don't take it too seriously and bite your teeth into it.Video:

												"Careful" yes...it's got more content than FO 1, more cars, more tracks, etc.However, the tracks feel very samey. There are different forest, farmland, canal, race and city tracks, which are very similar...what's the difference between "pines" and "logging camp" for example...pretty minor. The most interesting tracks only appear toward the end of the game, which is a shame, since the game is tiered into 3 different "classes" (derby, sports and street or sth. like that) and 1 class gets obsolete once you're done with it, only to buy the next best car in another class. Despite winning every race and event I still didn't have enough money to consistently buy new cars and fully upgrade them...and oh boy, do you need the new cars. Some cars are simply way better than others...sad story. I wasn't even bothering with the late game stuff. A pick up truck carried me throught the last 50 races or so.The driving and physics are ok, but FO 1 required a lot more senstivity. This game is for the most part pedal to the metal. Only in later classes and tiers will you ever need breaks, which is a shame. Or you could just rely on your AI opponents to simply crash into you to slow you down. I mean, yes, it is a "crash" game, but the AI is just nuts and a really bad driver. They will CONSTANTLY try to crash you, even if that means they wreck themselves (i.e. kill). They don't drive to win, they drive to crash. You. They go out of their way to get you, which is very annoying to be honest. I don't mind the crashing, it's fun, but there should be a race underneat, not a rubber band AI that crashes itself after every use of Nitro. The AI is bad. Very bad. Towards the end of the game it's so bad, that out of your 7 opponents, only 2 (sometimes 3) even pose a "challenge". Why? Because they constantly rubber band 1st and 2nd place. In. Every. Race. Unless you wreck them or crash them enough, so that they may only be in 4th or 5th place. This puts enormous amounts of pressure on the player to win every race, which is very hard if you drive perfectly, the AI crashes constantly, but still catches up multiple times. It makes no sense.What also does not make sense is the absurd amount of debris on the road, which your car either ignores or (perhaps when the game thinks you're doing too well) which flip you around like a leaf in the wind...inconsistent imho. Anyway, 14 hours for this game's SP mode...too much imho. Damn. The event games are cool, though, once you get the hang of them.

												My first instinct is to put a NO on recommending this game. That's because it's so often infuriating.The racing here is all about physics and destruction. You can crash into the scenery and your fellow racers, resulting in detailed and wild destruction.This is what makes the game both fun and frustrating. More often than not, finishing in first place is a matter of blind luck, thanks to all the scattered debris all over the tracks. I mean ALL over everywhere. The slightest bump will send you careening off into the side of the track. Same if you get bumped by a fellow racer.That's basically my only gripe with the game. Otherwise it's tons of fun. The damage model on the cars and environment is pretty great (I know, I was just complaining about them!) The career mode is nice and simple, varied, with a great selection of tracks and game modes and cars.Each car can also be upgraded in various ways. You could focus on speed and just go for the finish. You could focus on strength and make your car a high powered ram rod, disabling the competition.There's also the stunt levels where the already-filmsy realism is flung out through the windshield, just like your driver will be, flying into bowling pins or a velcro wall for points. Very silly, very difficult (at least for me), very fun.I haven't played other FlatOut games. People say this one is the best of the series. Check out the spiritual sequel, "Wreckfest / Next Car Game", here on Steam.

												My first instinct is to put a NO on recommending this game. That's because it's so often infuriating.The racing here is all about physics and destruction. You can crash into the scenery and your fellow racers, resulting in detailed and wild destruction.This is what makes the game both fun and frustrating. More often than not, finishing in first place is a matter of blind luck, thanks to all the scattered debris all over the tracks. I mean ALL over everywhere. The slightest bump will send you careening off into the side of the track. Same if you get bumped by a fellow racer.That's basically my only gripe with the game. Otherwise it's tons of fun. The damage model on the cars and environment is pretty great (I know, I was just complaining about them!) The career mode is nice and simple, varied, with a great selection of tracks and game modes and cars.Each car can also be upgraded in various ways. You could focus on speed and just go for the finish. You could focus on strength and make your car a high powered ram rod, disabling the competition.There's also the stunt levels where the already-filmsy realism is flung out through the windshield, just like your driver will be, flying into bowling pins or a velcro wall for points. Very silly, very difficult (at least for me), very fun.I haven't played other FlatOut games. People say this one is the best of the series. Check out the spiritual sequel, "Wreckfest / Next Car Game", here on Steam.

												Though this game gets a lot of praise it has some glaring flaws that you should be aware of, I'll touch on the good points first:*The car destruction looks very realistic, and you'll notice actual changes in handing as your car accrues more damage; when your car is badly damaged for example it will lose a wheel and handling will become a nightmare.*There are a wide variety of off and on-road environments to race on, from deserts, to cities, to forests, as well as some fun mini-games to add replay value. The named opponents and different driving styles also add some personality to the career mode.---However on the whole this game left me more frustrated than entralled, so now I'll get to the bad news:The handling in this game is just bad, to the point that it feels like you're driving a hovercraft rather than a car, and a single shunt or slight oversteer can sent you off the track into a wall. This is also counter-intuitive to the design of the game since you're encouraged to drive aggressive and crash into things, but when the margin for error is so high it's usually safer to avoid taking jumps or smashing into traffic lights.The single-player mode relies on the catch-up effect to prevent a single spinout from taking you out of the race, but in the (now-defunct) online multiplayer this is nonexistent - meaning a single oversteer or ram from an opponent in the first minute of the race can take you out, which is frustrating rather than fun in an acade racer.Aside from that, the game's musical score feels out of place for a destruction-oriented racing game, consisting mainly of pop punk, emo, and alternative rock tracks - it seems to have taken a cue from the Burnout series here. The graphics are also a little too bright and cheerful for my taste.The final notable flaw is the unbalanced cars. The game is divided into 3 classes of cars, and each class has 1 or 2 high-end cars which are far-and-away superior in every respect to the others in their class. In multiplayer this means that nearly everyone will just end up driving the same car in every race, while the others just go unused.While this isn't a terrible game, on the whole I consider it overhyped and overrated; though the single-player mode may offer a casual racing diversion to some.

In FlatOut 1 most of the clutter came from tyres from tyre walls, in FlatOut 2 you have all kinds of clutter that obscure the view of the track. Most of the clutter also has 'weight' which means that if you drive into it then you'll collide with it instead of just driving over it or through it. This normally wouldn't be so bad, but because there is so much clutter it usually covers the width of the track so you have no choice but to collide into it. Driving in 1st person mode it can get very tricky when this clutter attaches itself to the bonnet of the car, obscuring your entire view and making you have to change camera. That's just poor design.The game has partial controller support with the racing being fine with the gamepad but the menus are only navigational with a keyboard.Overall it's not a bad game, if you haven't played FlatOut 1. FlatOut 2 has more content, but I much preferred the track design and organic destruction of FlatOut 1.

												Flatout 2 has the same developer and publisher as the first game; and yet, somehow, they've managed to make it feel like a cheap Flatout ripoff.The innovative damage and driving system of the first game is gone, replaced with arcade style physics instead. Missing as well, is unlocking the entire tier of cars in one go, rather having to unlock individual cars as you compete, entirely precluding you from being able to save up for the car you want, and carry it through the tier with you, as with the previous game. Vehicle upgrades are also severely limited when compared to the first game as well, with only one tier for each upgrade, and many upgrades from the previous game being entirely absent. All the vehicles more or less handle the same, despite this game having differences between FWD, 4WD, and RWD cars, with weight and strength not coming into play at all with the exception of during derby events.Level design makes no logical sense, with entire structures appearing and disappearing with track layouts that are supposed to be in the same location. All the tracks feel as though they were designed as race tracks first, and the copy and pasted into the game's various locals, rather than designed from the ground up to suit that location. As a result, all of the tracks feel more or less the same, with different scenery adorning each one, rather than different and unique challenging locations.Gone as well is the previous game's unique soundtrack, replaced with generic pop and rock music. While I have nothing against the songs themselves, they take away from the "country and backwoods" feel of a derby-style racing game, and replace it with something that feels like it belongs in Need For Speed: Underground.All and all, I cannot recommend this game. It is held aloft almost entirely on the success of its predecessor, but with about half the production budget. I recommend buying the first game, and forgetting this travesty ever existed.

												 "An extreme classic which is a fast loading time consumer where you never have a clean race."Quite simply; Burnout with character. Burnout is all about crashing at speed, whilst Flatout 2 is much about racing with anyway possible. Whether it's smashing the opposition into trees or smashing through shops to gain nitro, every race is different, fun and action packed.If you enjoy burnout and/or Flatout, then this is perfect. Although Flatout based around 70's American muscle derby racing, Flatout 2 expands into tuner and exotic classes and even a school bus (best vehicle in the game). This gives it more variety and a more satisfying time. Of course, being a Flatout game, the bonus games are as silly and unique as before. Only this time the stunt cars have the minor addition of jet engines. There is also a character system, which tells you who is ahead and who you just T-boned off into a river. This can cause serious grudge matches and is useful for long championships. Overall, this game is simply an expansion of Flatout, with twice the destruction, twice the action, and of course, twice the fun.

												Flatout 2, in my opinion, is one of the best arcade raceing games you can find and I'm not just saying that because of the nostalgia I have for playing it on Playstation2.Pros:+Graphics: For a game that came out in 2006 on the Playstation 2, it looks amazing. I would even say it's Playstation 3 good.+Gameplay: The controls are simple but fun and there's plenty of gamemodes to make the price well worth it, from career mode to single races, minigames to demolition. The tracks are filled with hundreds of collidable and destructable objects to smash through, windows, furniture, billboards, fences, barn walls, ECT. The minigames are one of the best parts of the game, how can you not love hurling your drivers ragdoll body into a dart board or row of bowling pins?+Very little glitches: Ignore the hours Steam says that i have played because I've spend a good few dozen hours back on the PS2 and I hardly run into any glitches. Really the only ones I seem to find is the rare object floating or getting stuck in your car for a few seconds, nothing gamebreaking.+Soundtrack: The choice of music in Flatout 2 is amazing and I would dare say comparable to the older Tony Hawk games. Some of the bands featured in the game are Bad Religion, Megadeth, Yellowcard, Fallout Boy and Nickleback.Cons:- Controller support: Although you can use an Xbox 360 controller, it's only partially compadable, but to be honest I don't find it to be that big of a deal, just a bit annoying. You can't pause with the controller or navigate the menus, because controllers only work when racing.-No online support: Don't get this game if you're looking for a racing game to play with friend online, because it's a a port of a Playstation 2 game.-Sofia Martinez: ♥♥♥♥ that ♥♥♥♥♥! 												TL;DR - If you like arcade racers, you'll love this. Just buy it already.There are 3 classes of vehicles: derby, race and street. Nothing feels quite as satisfying as performing a PIT maneuver on JASON WALKER, THAT OVERPOWERED PIECE OF♥♥♥♥♥♥ That said, it should be noted that the races are a bit easy to begin with and there's no real way to make it more difficult other than getting to the race/street classes.As well as races there are special 'events' such as bowling, darts and football/soccer. These mostly just involve flinging your driver at high speeds into something. These are extremely entertaining, but good luck winning 1st place!For the most part, the physics feel pretty solid. For some reason the handling feels weird with the chase cameras, so I would recommend using the 1st person or nose camera (if that's what they're called).I use a wired Xbox 360 controller to play this. 												Here it is, the sequel to a timeless classic, but is it better or worse? Well, a large majority will likely say the former, while looking through a pair of rose-tinted Nostalgia-brand glasses.Me? not so much.There are some big improvements over Flatout 1, but some problems have been made significantly worse. First, lets start with the driving.DRIVING:The driving feels overall pretty solid and nice, arcadey, but not to the extent of say, need for speed. Its sort of a blend of realistic behavor with physics breaking abilities. So far, its pretty good. Front-wheel drive cars tend to understeer into corners, rear-wheel drive tends to slide around more, oversteering, and 4WD is a bit of both, mostly understeer though. All well and good and as it should be. However Sometimes it can be very very unpredictable. Sometimes when landing a jump, your car will smash into the ground, either bouncing into the air or veering to the left or right, causing you to wreck, sometimes your car will completly flip upon landing a jump. THis all depends on the car, but really it can be complete luck weather you land a jump and keep going or crash and have to restart the race, which you will be doing, ALOT.Next, the tracksTRACKS:Oh, dear lord did they mess this one up badly.You know that thing i said in my Flatout 1 review?Originally posted by Spitfiredwod:Some objects are badly placed on tracks, like excavators,trucks,tractors ect all being placed in bad areas, wich can cause unneeded or undeserved wrecks, it also makes it harder to get a good driving line through certain corners. Sometimes even the tinest of objects like cones, can cause huge wrecks too. Yeah, well imagine that, only about ten-thousand times worse.Holy moly did they go overboard on the smashable props! It wouldnt really even be so much of a problem, if said props dissapeared or became uncollideable after being smashed into, but, no.The props just go everywhere, all over the track at critical points before turns or after jumps, and ALL of them will cause you to wreck, every single one, even the cardboard boxes.These props are everywhere, on every track in the game, and they are nearly impossible to avoid.Id say, out of the hundreds of wrecks that ive had in the game so far, 98% of them have not been my fault, 78% is likely due to the props, and at least 20% are due to the bad AI, which we'll get to later.Not to mention, the unbreakable solid objects badly placed on the edges of the track are still here, though, they are usually just boulders instead of trucks or diggers. However they are all pretty much completely hidden by grass, you wont know its there until you've hit one, and half the time you'll be saying "What the f**k did i just hit?" as you restart your race for the 17th time in a row, and no, thats not and exaggeration.THE AI:Im just going to be blunt here.This game has the worst AI rubberbanding ive ever seen in a racing game, ive been playing racing games for 12 years, many have had AI rubberbanding, but this one tops them all.To give a little explanation on this, ill use Gran Turismo 1/ Gran Turismo 2 for example, games nutorious for having AI rubberbanding.In GT1 and GT2 The AI would speed up or slow down depending on how much you were beating them, or them beating you. THis is used in an attempt to keep the racing close and fair.If you got 2 seconds a lap ahead, the AI would speed up a bit, usually matching your speed, your able to stay out in front, but if you make a really bad turn or crash, they will catch back up, or pass you. If your in a really fast car, you can outrun the speed boost. The same thing applies if your being beaten, the AI cars slow down by 2 seconds, giving you a chance to catch up, or pass them if you wrecked.Thats essentially what its like here, only its done way, way worse.Instead of your cars being equally matched, In street class, the AI cars will be almost twice as fast as your car, no matter what car it is or if its fully upgraded. The race starts and your left in the dust. then they brake a bit, allowing you to pass, only to smash you to bits or fly right past you once again.Basically, it doesnt matter how good of a driver you are, no amount of perfect driving lines or well timed boosts is going to give you an edge. The AI is basically there to stomp you, and you have to either get out in front and drive nearly perfect to stay there, which due to the AIs speed, wont last long, Or you and try and smash everyone who gets near you to peices. Either way, its racing hell.Finally, the multiplayer.MULTIPLAYER:The multiplayer is where the real fun lies. No garbage AI to ruin your day here, and usually less props get involved, due to  less people smashing into them. (though some are unaviodable and automatic, like the rock slide on Pinegrove.)The game has, or, had real online multiplayer, which was a huge plus over Flatout 1. However in late 2012 rumors that GameSpy, the company responsible for Hosting Flatout 2's online servers, and many many other games , would be shutting down. This would sadly prove true, as on May 31st 2013, Gamespy shut its doors for good, and took all of its servers with it..However, its not all bad, nowadays you can use many different programs to play GameSpy hosted games online, Flatout included. The multiplayer on Flatout 2 is very fun, you can race with, or smash other real players to bits. You can host lobbies with up to 8 players. As a host, you can change what tracks will be raced, what derbies or events will take place, what cars players will be able to use, how many laps a race will have, and so on.  Theres also text, and voice chat in lobbies. Ive never seen anyone using a microphone though, so i cant really answer to the quality of voice chat.OTHER STUFF;The Soundtrack here is pretty great, aside from the 2 Nickelback songs that is. Theres songs from, and not limited to:MegadethPapa RoachFall Out BoyRise AgainstWolfmotherRob ZombieThere havent been any really noticable bugs in what ive seen so far, aside from one minor glitch, where you can drive through a wall on a City track, however the glitch is useless, and wont give you a competitive edge.OVERALL;While i do reccomend this, because it can be quite fun, its also very frustrating at times. Be prepared to restart races 10-15 times to win.7/10.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												FlatOut 2 is now available for many years. It is racing game which handles a good balance between simulation and arcade and players who prefer either of the genres still will admit that it is an excellent fit. The game is playable on multiplayer and has several different types of single player modes. The most important is naturally the career mode. It contains thoughout its progress all other modes in a well mixed compilation.One cannot choose a difficulty, however the game has a very fair difficulty development which never gets unfair, but is mostly challenging. There are three types of car classes. Each has its own event plan and you have to beat all the events of one class to unlock the next one. The cars of every new class are harder to handle since they are getting faster and faster. Within the classes there is a development of the difficulty too because in each class you unlock better cars which raise the difficulty for the above stated reason. You can choose between four car types. There is the light small one with a good acceleration. The big and heavy one favourable for crashing. The normal inbetween which is balanced. The fast type which you usually unlock in each class after a few races. Specially the first three types have have different types of gameplay according to their strengths and weaknesses wherefore you have a different gaming experience in each of them. Each car can be also performance tuned with various parts which you can buy (visually the cars don't change).The career consists of trophies which consist of normal races. But there are also (Destruction) Derbies where your main challenge is to survive as long as possible while crashing other cars and gaining points to win the competition. Moreover the career has every now and then fun events which gameplay bases on launching your driver through the front window in different games which are generally based on different real world sports. You have seven opponents throughout the game which have their own names and portraits and each of them has his own an unique style of driving and usage of car types. The opponents are getting better with further progress in the game as you do. It is also worth to mention that your competitors in the races don't react any different to bots than to you. The tracks you drive on are very various and are always well mixed when compilated in trophies. There are no parts which repeat unnecessarily which is a reason why the gaming experience is till the very end so much fun.Very much in the game is about crashing other cars. You get star ratings for each crash which results in higher income. It is possible to wreck your opponents totally which upmost important in derbies. Also your nitro charges with crashing into opponents as well as into evironmental objects. Specially towards the ending of the game it gets a strategic character to gain nitro. The fun events are often really challenging and if you beat them you still have the urge to beat highscores. But FlatOut 2 is still a racing game. If you don't want to crash you don't have to. This counts for the trophies. In derbies and fun events you obviously have a different main task.Another point that has a huge impact on the gaming experience is the tracklist (music) that is played in the races. It fits perfectly and it emphasizes the characteristics of the game strongly.The best way to play this game is with friends with in local network. You can create tournaments with all the different tracks and events you like and it has because of its competitiveness a similar multiplayer experience like Mario Kart.Since the game is not very expensive anymore and appears often on sales I warmly and highly recommend this game for everyone who is at least slightly interested in racing games.Edit:I've played it again and still not getting tired of it.

												FlatOut 2 takes me back to the days of playing the scaled-down version on the PSP. It's the same fun game, but with beefed-up graphics and an insanely smooth frame-rate. Like with just about every old game I own, I search for ways to increase the graphics past what's available in the game settings. The game looks great on its own (My goodness.. has it stood the test of time!) but with some added ambient occlusion (HBAO+ via Nvidia Inspector, flag: 0x0000001F) and brute-force anti-aliasing (SGSSAA via Nvidia Inspector, no flag needed), FlatOut 2's age is significantly less noticeable. I'm aware of the better graphics in Ultimate Carnage, but there's something in FlatOut 2's gameplay that I like better. The gameplay feels identical to Head On on the PSP which is what I'm used to. Just one flaw I can think of (not a big one) is the lack of buttons you can map to a gamepad. I used Xpadder to map the last few buttons to my DualShock 4 such as Esc, Enter and arrows keys (to navigate the menu and pause the game). Awesome, fast-paced game. I recommend. Ignore my play time on Steam. I used to play a pirated copy when built my first PC in 2010. I just decided to buy it today because... 2 bucks.EDIT: Idk if this applies for everyone, but for G-Sync users, there is noticeable motion jittering when the frame-rate isn't locked at 50 or at the default limit, 100. Any frame-rate that isn't a steady 50 or steady 100 will make motion look ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Ehh.. most people probably don't notice. I notice, but that's because I'm a smooth gameplay junkie.
